hints.label: def-algorithmic-space-generic
hints.title: Algorithmic Space
hints.raw_directive:
1256: ### 6.1 Specification of the Algorithmic Space ({prf:ref}`def-algorithmic-space-generic`)
1257: :::{prf:definition} Algorithmic Space
1258: :label: def-algorithmic-space-generic
1259: An **algorithmic space ({prf:ref}`def-algorithmic-space-generic`)** is a pair $(\mathcal{Y}, d_{\mathcal{Y}})$ consisting of a real vector space $\mathcal{Y}$ and a true metric $d_{\mathcal{Y}}$ ({prf:ref}`axiom-bounded-algorithmic-diameter`) on $\mathcal{Y}$, built on the Ambient Euclidean Structure ({prf:ref}`def-ambient-euclidean`).

hints.label: def-distance-positional-measures
hints.title: Distance Between Positional Measures
hints.content:
1264: :label: def-distance-positional-measures
1265: Let two walkers ({prf:ref}`def-walker`), $i$ and $j$, have their positions represented by the Dirac positional measures $\delta_{x_i}$ and $\delta_{x_j}$. The distance between them in the algorithmic space ({prf:ref}`def-algorithmic-space-generic`) is the **1-Wasserstein distance ($W_1$)** between their **projected positional measures**, with $d_{\mathcal{Y}}$ ({prf:ref}`axiom-bounded-algorithmic-diameter`) as the ground metric.
1266: The projected positional measure for walker ({prf:ref}`def-walker`) $i$ is the pushforward measure $\varphi_* \delta_{x_i} = \delta_{\varphi(x_i)}$. The distance is then:
1267: 
1268: $$
1269: 
1270: d(\varphi_* \delta_{x_i}, \varphi_* \delta_{x_j}) := W_1(\delta_{\varphi(x_i)}, \delta_{\varphi(x_j)})
1271: 
1272: $$
hints.raw_directive:
1262: The distance between two walker ({prf:ref}`def-walker`)s is formally defined as the distance between the probability measures representing their positions.
1263: :::{prf:definition} Distance Between Positional Measures
1264: :label: def-distance-positional-measures
1265: Let two walkers ({prf:ref}`def-walker`), $i$ and $j$, have their positions represented by the Dirac positional measures $\delta_{x_i}$ and $\delta_{x_j}$. The distance between them in the algorithmic space ({prf:ref}`def-algorithmic-space-generic`) is the **1-Wasserstein distance ($W_1$)** between their **projected positional measures**, with $d_{\mathcal{Y}}$ ({prf:ref}`axiom-bounded-algorithmic-diameter`) as the ground metric.
1266: The projected positional measure for walker ({prf:ref}`def-walker`) $i$ is the pushforward measure $\varphi_* \delta_{x_i} = \delta_{\varphi(x_i)}$. The distance is then:
1267: 
1268: $$
1269: 
1270: d(\varphi_* \delta_{x_i}, \varphi_* \delta_{x_j}) := W_1(\delta_{\varphi(x_i)}, \delta_{\varphi(x_j)})
1271: 
1272: $$
1273: For Dirac measures, the Wasserstein distance simplifies to the ground metric distance between their points of support.

hints.label: def-alg-distance
hints.title: Algorithmic Distance
hints.content:
1277: :label: def-alg-distance
1278: The **algorithmic distance ({prf:ref}`def-alg-distance`)** $d_{\text{alg}}\colon\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}$ is the distance between the projected positional measures ({prf:ref}`def-distance-positional-measures`) of two walkers ({prf:ref}`def-walker`). In practice, this is the distance or semidistance function $d_{\mathcal{Y}}$ ({prf:ref}`axiom-bounded-algorithmic-diameter`) applied to the projected points in the algorithmic space ({prf:ref}`def-algorithmic-space-generic`):
1279: 
1280: $$
1281: 
1282: \boxed{d_{\text{alg}}(x_1, x_2) := d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(x_1), \varphi(x_2))}
1283: 
1284: $$
hints.raw_directive:
1275: ### 6.3 Algorithmic Distance
1276: :::{prf:definition} Algorithmic Distance
1277: :label: def-alg-distance
1278: The **algorithmic distance ({prf:ref}`def-alg-distance`)** $d_{\text{alg}}\colon\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}$ is the distance between the projected positional measures ({prf:ref}`def-distance-positional-measures`) of two walkers ({prf:ref}`def-walker`). In practice, this is the distance or semidistance function $d_{\mathcal{Y}}$ ({prf:ref}`axiom-bounded-algorithmic-diameter`) applied to the projected points in the algorithmic space ({prf:ref}`def-algorithmic-space-generic`):
1279: 
1280: $$
1281: 
1282: \boxed{d_{\text{alg}}(x_1, x_2) := d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(x_1), \varphi(x_2))}
1283: 
1284: $$
1285: This is the practical implementation of the Wasserstein distance between the walker ({prf:ref}`def-walker`)s' projected Dirac measures and serves as the ground distance for all subsequent calculations.
